oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Sawyer Brown Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Sawyer Brown (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Sawyer Brown; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie and Mark Miller, of Sawyer Brown, talk about the number of times it took to cut "Leona" while touching on Randy Scruggs' involvement -- (00:52) Collie and Miller reflect on hearing "It's Only Rock n' Roll" while Miller discusses his struggle to establish himself as a country artist -- (03:01) Miller and Gregg 'Hobie' Hubbard talk about their growing popularity through a television show; This caused him to sign with Capitol Records -- (04:48) Miller radio spot introducing himself, Sawyer Brown and Biff Collie for the Music City Album Review -- (05:00) Hubbard radio spot introducing himself, Miller, Sawyer Brown and Biff Collie for the Music City Album Review -- (05:08) Hubbard radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (05:19) Miller radio spot introducing himself, Hubbard, Sawyer Brown and Biff Collie for the Music City Album Review -- (05:29) Miller radio spot introducing himself, Sawyer Brown and Biff Collie for the Music City Album Review -- (05:40) Hubbard radio spot for driving safely and the Music City Album Review -- (05:49) Hubbard and Miller radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (05:56) Hubbard and Miller radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (06:02) Hubbard and Miller radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (06:12) Hubbard half-hour radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (06:18) Miller half-way radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (6:27) Hubbard and Miller, thirty minute remaining, radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (06:36) Hubbard and Miller radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (06:44) Miller radio spot asking the audience if they enjoyed the show -- (06:48) Hubbard asking the audience to join the Music City Album Review next week -- (06:54) Miller talks about working with Scruggs and fan pressures -- (07:25) Miller talks about "Puttin' the Dark Back into the Night" being originally a ballad song -- (07:51) "Rosie Knows" is discussed by Collie asking, "who is Rosie?" and Miller and Hubbard tell of how she is more of a feeling then an actual person -- (08:38) Sawyer Brown Road in Western Nashville is discussed as the inspiration for the band name -- (09:25) "Did it For Love" is touched on by Miller as a universal chorus -- (10:36) Hubbard tells of a Star Search audience that they had not given too much effort; although, they left a lasting impression -- (12:10) Miller talks about the turn around of popularity due to Star Search -- (12:25) Collie and Hubbard discuss the Star Search show as a building block to their live show performances -- (14:00) Miller talks about Hubbard's odd fashion and tells of the first cover song, "The Race is On," Sawyer Brown had ever recorded -- (16:01) Miller tells of the success of "The Race is On" and Collie reflects on the songs parallel image to Sawyer Brown with Hubbard -- (16:53) Collie praises Miller's energy and Miller reflects on the music's influence on his energy -- (17:47) Collie compares Miller to Chuck Berry and Miller connects the band to older country legends -- (18:18) Miller and Hubbard tell of how they select what music videos they decide to shoot -- (19:01) "Hey, Hey" is discussed by Hubbard as an a-typical Sawyer Brown type song -- (19:36) "Good While it Lasted" writer Bill LaBounty is reflected on as someone who believed in Sawyer Brown from the beginning -- (20:33) Miller tells of growing up in Florida with Hubbard and tells how the rest of the band grew up in Michigan before getting a job as a house band for Knights Corral -- (21:37) Hubbard reflects on how they received work through word of mouth -- (22:18) "Locomotive" is discussed by Miller as a crazy train -- (22:57) Hubbard talks about "Locomotive" as a song that has a Sawyer Brown feeling -- (23:22) Miller tells how their ability to work is the best part of being a part of Sawyer Brown -- (23:57) Collie and Miller discuss how Sawyer Brown had been the opening act for Kenny Rogers and Dolly Parton -- (25:12) "The Heartland" is discussed as a track that required multiple cuts to get right -- (26:04) Collie and Miller reflect on the polarizing ability of Sawyer Brown -- (26:44) "I'm Gonna Miss You After All" is a song reflected on by Miller that was brought to him from his basketball league -- (27:31) Collie and Miller reflect on Miller's athletic career; Miller includes a tale of walking off his team -- (28:30) "Gettin' Tough (Good Ol' Boy)" is reflected on by Collie and Hubbard as a song about a changing man -- (29:20) Collie inquires about Sawyer Brown's favorite acts and Miller discusses Alabama, Vern Gosdin, Bob Seger, Billy Joel, Elton John and Paul McCartney -- (30:34) Collie and Hubbard talk about how he acquired the nickname "Hobie" -- (31:14) "Passing Train" is answered by Hubbard as a tale of the mysteries associated with time -- (31:57) Collie brings up Sawyer Brown's extra-curricular activities and Miller reflects on Sawyer Brown's appreciation for the position the band is in allowing for them to donate money to a good cause -- (35:02) Hubbard, Miller, and Collie joke about the Sound of Music and Hubbard shows his appreciation for the fans -- (35:40) Miller and Hubbard say goodbye
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Sawyer Brown (Musical group); Sawyer Brown;
